The Clemson product profiles as a perimeter receiver (19% slot last season) who will do a lot of his damage downfield (14.6 aDOT) and near the goal line. Higgins averaged 3.8 yards per route run in 2019, which was second-best in this year's rookie class. Higgins has the talent to eventually emerge as a fantasy force (and perhaps even Joe Burrow's top target), but it might take some time for him to see the field, with Green, Tyler Boyd and John Ross also on the 2020 depth chart. He's barely worth a late-round pick in 2020 leagues.

name: Brandon Aiyuk
bio: San Francisco selected Aiyuk with the 25th pick of April's draft. Aiyuk comes in at 6-foot, 205 pounds with 4.50 40-yard speed, as well as terrific explosiveness and route-running ability. The Arizona State product's best asset is his post-catch production (10.5 RAC in 2019), which helped him to plenty of big plays at ASU. Aiyuk doesn't have a ton of competition for early-career snaps, but he should be considered a long shot for weekly fantasy value in a super-run-heavy 49ers' offense that will lean heavily on George Kittle and Deebo Samuel. He's worth only a late-round pick.

name: Chris Godwin
bio: Godwin is entering his fourth NFL season and his second as a full-time player. His first season as a full-timer went, in a word, well. Inexplicably a situational player under Dirk Koetter, Godwin finished 2019 ranked as a top-10 WR in snaps, routes, yardage and touchdowns. He finished fourth at the position in catch rate (72%) and RAC (6.6) and was first in first-down rate (50%). Godwin is a candidate for touchdown regression (9 TD, 5.1 OTD) in 2020 and will have a new quarterback in Tom Brady, but the 24-year-old appears to be the real deal. Consider him as a solid WR1.

name: Jarvis Landry
bio: Landry was expected to see a big dip in production last season following the Browns' trade for Odell Beckham Jr. Instead, Cleveland's slot man had one of his best NFL seasons and actually out-targeted his teammate 139-132. Landry set a career-high in receiving yardage (1,174) and YPR (14.1) en route to his fifth consecutive top-18 fantasy campaign. Landry has proved to be super reliable, having never missed a game in six seasons and checking in as one of just six players who were targeted in 100% of his 2019 games. New coach Kevin Stefanski could shake things up a bit, but Landry's connection with Baker Mayfield is solid, making him a fine WR3 target.

name: Jamison Crowder
bio: Crowder has emerged as one of the game's top slot/short-area targets and that skill was on full display in his first season with the Jets. The longtime slot man in Washington posted a healthy 78-833-6 receiving line in New York, leading to a 26th-place finish in fantasy points. Crowder finished near the basement of the position in aDOT (8.1) for the fifth time in as many seasons, which limited big plays (6.8 YPT), but allowed him to soak up receptions (16th most). At 5-foot-8, 185 pounds, Crowder won't get you many touchdowns. Heck, he has only 20 career end zone targets. Still, Sam Darnold's top option will catch enough passes to allow for flex production in PPR leagues.

name: Marquise Brown
bio: Baltimore selected Brown in the first round of the 2019 draft and the speedster was immediately slotted in as the team's top wide receiver by default. Brown's boom/bust rookie campaign began with his best game in Week 1 (4-147-2) followed by mixed results (including a pair of missed games) the rest of the way. Brown ended up as the WR46 on the season, thanks to seven touchdowns on 69 targets. His 10.1% TD rate was second highest at the position and certainly unsustainable. Brown is an obvious bet for a boost in targets in his second season as Lamar Jackson's top perimeter target. The 23-year-old is a breakout candidate and a sharp flex target.

name: Russell Gage
bio: Gage is an intriguing deep sleeper this season after the Falcons failed to address the WR position during free agency and the draft. The 2018 sixth-round pick was promoted to slot duties in Atlanta's pass-heavy offense last season following the trade of Mohamed Sanu. Counting only weeks in which Julio Jones and Calvin Ridley also played, Gage handled a 16% target share and was the WR40 for fantasy. Especially with Austin Hooper no longer in the fold, Gage is well-positioned for a similar role in his third NFL season. Consider him late in deep PPR leagues.

name: DeVante Parker
bio: It's not often that a player realizes his potential in his fifth NFL season, but that was exactly what happened for Parker last season. After failing to post a single top-50 campaign while totaling nine touchdowns during his first four seasons in Miami, Parker exploded for a 72-1,202-9 receiving line in his first year working with Brian Flores. He ended up as fantasy's No. 11 WR and finished top five in routes run, receiving yards and touchdowns. The 27-year-old has first-round pedigree and had suffered through several injuries, so the leap wasn't a major shock, but we also should proceed with caution in 2020. Miami's top offensive target is safest when targeted as a WR3.

name: Michael Gallup
bio: Most would agree that Gallup is the Cowboys' No. 2 wideout behind Amari Cooper, but it's not as clear-cut as you might think. In 13 full games together last season, Gallup played on 44 more snaps and was targeted four more times than his counterpart. Both were top-10 fantasy receivers during those weeks. Gallup looks like the real deal following a breakout second season in which he posted a 66-1,107-6 receiving line and ranked ninth among wide receivers with a 16.8 YPR. The 24-year-old has solidified himself as one of Dak Prescott's go-to targets and, even though his workload could drop slightly with CeeDee Lamb in the mix, he could make up for some of that with more usage near the goal line. He had only three end-zone targets last season. Consider Gallup as a borderline WR3.

name: Jerry Jeudy
bio: Denver selected Jeudy with the 15th pick of April's draft. The Alabama product sports a 6-foot-1, 193-pound frame and is extremely versatile, having shown the ability to produce on all levels, as well as in the slot (69% in 2019) and on the perimeter. Jeudy is fast (4.45 40-yard dash), agile and a quality route-runner. Jeudy slots in behind Courtland Sutton but has little competition for snaps otherwise and should be an every-down player out of the gate. Jeudy has WR1 upside down the road but should be viewed as a shaky flex option for 2020 in a run-heavy Broncos offense and with Drew Lock still an unknown.

name: T.Y. Hilton
bio: Hilton enters 2020 looking for a rebound following what was essentially a lost season. As if Andrew Luck's shocking August retirement wasn't enough, injuries limited Hilton to only 10 games and a situational role in the second half of the campaign. Hilton was still effective when healthy, ranking 13th in fantasy points during the six weeks he was active prior to Week 9. Hilton is now 30 years old, but has generally held up well, missing only four games during his first seven seasons. He will now have Philip Rivers throwing him passes. Hilton was a top-27 fantasy WR during each of his first seven seasons and remains very much in the WR2 discussion for 2020.

name: Emmanuel Sanders
bio: Sanders is now 33, but the veteran receiver is well-situated for another season of fantasy relevance after signing with the high-scoring Saints. Sanders is no longer the target hog he was during his prime, but he has nonetheless managed a pair of top-30 fantasy campaigns over the past two seasons. Sanders has seen top-10 finishes in catch rate in both of the past two seasons and figures to work as one of Drew Brees' top targets in the short-to-intermediate area behind Michael Thomas. Sanders is unlikely to be a major asset near the goal line, as he has cleared six touchdowns in a season just once in his career. Nevertheless, he'll see enough volume to warrant weekly flex consideration.

name: Sterling Shepard
bio: Shepard has been a tricky player to figure out so far. The 2016 second-round pick has finished two seasons among the top-eight WRs in routes run, but he's also missed five-plus games in two different seasons and he's yet to finish any season better than No. 30 in fantasy points. Shepard replaced Odell Beckham Jr. as the Giants' No. 1 WR last season -- and he was very busy, handling six-plus targets during all 10 appearances. Only five other players can say the same. Shepard's efficiency was poor, but the volume allowed him the 17th-most fantasy points during those 10 weeks. Shepard will have more competition with a healthier group around him this season, but he's still a legitimate candidate to lead the team in targets. Don't sleep on the 26-year-old when flex hunting.

name: Mike Williams
bio: Slowly but surely, Williams' pro career continues to progress. The 2017 first-round pick barely played as a rookie, posting a 43-664-10 receiving line in a situational role in 2018. He followed that up with a 49-1,001-2 line as a full-time player in 2019. Last season, Williams paced the NFL in aDOT (17.3) and YPR (20.4) and ranked fourth in YPT (11.0), but dealt with the worst luck in the league in the touchdown department. Williams posted a 6.9 OTD thanks to 11 end-zone targets (tied for eighth most), but scored only twice. The 25-year-old is a strong bet for more touchdowns, but the departure of Philip Rivers hurts his stock. Williams is a more appealing flex choice in non-PPR leagues.

name: Julio Jones
bio: Jones is now 31 years old but remains an elite fantasy weapon as Matt Ryan's top target in the pass-heavy Atlanta offense. Jones continues to underwhelm in the touchdown department (only 6.2 scores per season since 2014), but he more than makes up for it with both massive targets (10.5 per game over the past two seasons) and receiving yardage (ranked among the top three WRs in each of the past six seasons). Jones' career-low YPT and RAC marks last season are a slight concern for a player now in his 30s, but his heavy usage positions him well for a run at a seventh straight top-seven fantasy campaign. Draft him in the second round.

name: DJ Chark Jr.
bio: Chark entered 2019 with little fanfare, despite the fact that he was a second-round pick entering his second NFL season and positioned for a significant boost in playing time. It didn't take long for the former LSU star to get noticed. Despite Jacksonville's offensive dysfunction, Chark posted a 73-1,008-8 receiving line. His 12 end-zone targets (over 15 contests) tied for fifth most in the league and only 16 receivers scored more fantasy points. Chark is 23 years old with the size and speed to sustain top-tier production. With Gardner Minshew entering his second season and Jay Gruden perhaps adding a spark to the offense, Chark has the look of a good WR3 with upside.

name: Darius Slayton
bio: In a performance that was eerily similar (albeit not quite as dominant) to the one of the man he helped replace (Odell Beckham Jr.), Slayton missed the first two games of his rookie season before bursting onto the fantasy scene with eight touchdowns in 14 games. Slayton was on the field for 77% of the Giants' pass plays and was WR27 in fantasy points from Week 3 on. Slayton's touchdown rate is far from sustainable (3.5 OTD), but the 2019 fifth-round pick will enter his second season as New York's primary vertical threat. The New York offense has a lot of mouths to feed, but there's certainly a window for Slayton to become the team's No. 1 wideout. Slayton is safest as a flex in deeper leagues.

name: Travis Kelce
bio: Kelce enters the 2020 season attempting to pace all tight ends in fantasy points for the fifth consecutive season. Is that good? It seems good. Kelce continued his dominance last season by finishing as a top-13 fantasy TE every week other than 17. Kelce has finished no lower than second at the position in routes, targets, receptions and yardage each of the past three seasons. His touchdowns fell from 10 in 2018 to five in 2019, but his 7.3 OTD (second-highest) and nine end zone targets (fourth) suggest he was actually unlucky in that area. Kelce has never finished a season outside the top 10 in YPT and remains one of Patrick Mahomes' top targets. The 30-year-old is worth a look in Round 2.

name: Darren Waller
bio: Waller's breakout 2019 season marked one of the most improbable breakout campaigns you'll ever see. Waller was drafted in the sixth round of the 2015 draft as a 6-foot-6 wide receiver. He barely saw the field while dealing with addiction but got back on his feet as a tight end with the Raiders. An absolute force from the get-go, Waller finished no lower than fourth among tight ends in snaps, routes, targets, receptions, yardage or YPT. Waller was held to three touchdowns (3.9 OTD) but finished third in fantasy points. The 27-year-old is Derek Carr's top target and positioned well for another high-volume season. He's a top-five fantasy tight end.

name: T.J. Hockenson
bio: It's rare for a rookie tight end to make much noise in fantasy, so Hockenson's 32-367-2 line after being selected eighth overall in the 2019 draft should not be viewed as a knock. The Iowa product showed his upside with a 6-131-1 showing in his NFL debut, but managed double-digit fantasy points in only one additional game and missed the final four games due to injury. The 23-year-old is a strong bet for more work in his second season and, as usual for second-year tight ends, will come fairly cheap in the double-digit rounds. Hockenson has the upside to become one of the next great all-around tight ends.

name: Mark Andrews
bio: A 2018 third-round pick, Andrews exited his rookie campaign seemingly set to become one of the league's next great tight ends. It's fair to say he delivered the goods in 2019. Despite ranking 40th at the position in snaps, Andrews handled a massive 25% target share for Baltimore's league-best offense en route to a TE5 fantasy campaign. Andrews' 11 end zone targets tied for most among tight ends and eighth in the entire league. That helped him to 10 touchdowns. Andrews' has ranked no lower than fifth in aDOT or YPR during his two pro seasons. Lamar Jackson's top target enters his age-24 season as a solid TE1 option.

name: Mike Gesicki
bio: It was a rough 2019 season for the Dolphins, but that didn't stop Gesicki from quietly taking a big leap forward. The 2018 second-round pick finished the season third among tight ends in pass routes and ranked no lower than 12th in targets, receptions, receiving yards or touchdowns. Gesicki's 11 end zone targets tied for most among tight ends and eighth in the entire league. His 58% catch rate was ugly, but his role as a seam-stretcher (10.1 aDOT) and shaky quarterback accuracy (22% off target rate) were the primary culprits. Gesicki has yet to drop a pass on 120 targets and was fantasy's TE12 in 2019. He's a candidate for another leap forward and a borderline TE1 option.

name: Rob Gronkowski
bio: Gronk is back! The longtime Patriots' superstar ended his retirement and was traded to the Buccaneers, where he'll reunite with his former quarterback Tom Brady. Gronkowski sat out last season after ending 2018 with his seventh fantasy finish of 11th or better in nine NFL seasons. When healthy, effectiveness has never been an issue for Gronkowski (he has never played a season in which he was lower than seventh among tight ends in yards per target or yards per reception), but durability has been an issue (he hasn't appeared in a full 16-game regular season since 2011).'Gronkowski is unlikely to re-emerge as an elite fantasy option, but he's in a good enough situation to allow mid-to-back-end TE1 numbers.

name: Noah Fant
bio: The Broncos selected Fant in the first round of last year's draft and proceeded to put him on the field for 68% of their offensive snaps. That's a healthy number for a 21-year-old rookie, as was Fant's TE16 fantasy campaign. The Iowa product was a game-changer with the ball in his hands, pacing 41 qualified tight ends with an 8.3 RAC. His 562 receiving yards rank sixth and his 8.9 YPT fifth among rookie tight ends since 2007. Fant's usage actually declined quite a bit in December, but there's little doubt he's a strong candidate for a big second-year leap as one of Drew Lock's top targets. Fant has elite upside and should be on your radar in the middle rounds.

name: Hunter Henry
bio: Henry is back with the Chargers after the team applied the franchise tag during the offseason. The team's 2016 second-round pick has yet to play a full 16-game season, missing all of 2018 and a total of seven games the other three seasons. That includes four in 2019, though Henry was productive enough when active to produce his first top-10 fantasy campaign. Henry has finished top-10 in YPT in all three of his NFL seasons and has been a force near the goal line, with 17 touchdowns and 25 end zone targets in 41 games. Henry's durability woes and the departure of Philip Rivers are concerns, but the 25-year-old will still be a back-end TE1 option when active.

name: Hayden Hurst
bio: Hurst was traded to the Falcons following two seasons as a situational player in Baltimore. Atlanta will look to the 2018 first-round pick as a replacement for Austin Hooper. Hurst posted a modest 30-349-2 receiving line off the bench last season, but his efficiency was great. He ranked sixth at tight end in both catch rate (77%) and YPT (8.9). Hurst has yet to eclipse a 58% snap share in 30 career games, but he figures to operate as a full-time, two-way tight end in a pass-heavy Atlanta offense that helped Hooper to back-to-back TE1 campaigns. Hurst is obviously a bit risky, but the 26-year-old is well-positioned for a breakout. Consider him a mid-range TE2.

name: Evan Engram
bio: Engram is entering his fourth NFL season having missed 14 of 48 possible games due to injury, including five games in 2018 and eight last season. The injuries have held Engram without a top-12 fantasy campaign since 2017, but there's no doubt he's been a major force when healthy. Engram was one of six players who appeared in at least eight games and were targeted at least six times during 100% of those outings last season. The consistent usage helped him to five top-10 fantasy weeks in eight tries (the position's fourth-best rate). We have to knock him a bit for durability concerns, but Engram is still in his prime at age 25 and should be locked into lineups when active.

name: Eric Ebron
bio: Ebron signed with the Steelers after spending the first six seasons of his career in Detroit and Indianapolis. The 2014 first-round pick underachieved during his time with the Lions, but a breakout season in 2018 saw him post a 66-750-13 receiving line. He crashed back to earth last season thanks to predictable regression to the mean, but also due to the loss of Andrew Luck, posting a 31-375-3 line in 11 games. Now with Pittsburgh, the 27-year-old figures to work ahead of Vance McDonald as the team's top receiving tight end. Ebron is best-viewed as a mid-to-back-end TE2.

name: Jimmy Graham
bio: Graham signed with the Bears during the offseason following a pair of seasons with the division-rival Packers. The 33-year-old isn't the fantasy force he was during his prime years in New Orleans and Seattle and is coming off his worst statistical season since his rookie year. Graham played 55% of the snaps, handled a 12% target share and posted a 38-447-3 receiving line despite appearing in all 16 of Green Bay's regular-season games. Graham finished eighth at tight end in pass routes, but 21st in fantasy points. Graham figures to contribute as a seam-stretcher in Chicago, but he'll be a part-time player in an offense with a shaky quarterback situation. Consider him a back-end TE2.

name: George Kittle
bio: Kittle wasn't much of a factor as a pass-catcher during the 49ers' Super Bowl run (8-71-0 in three games), but don't let that overshadow what was another dominant regular season. Kittle followed up his breakout 2018 season with an 85-1053-5 receiving line in 14 games in 2019. Kittle has finished no lower than fourth in targets, receptions, yardage, RAC or fantasy points each of the past two seasons. One area where Kittle has underwhelmed is touchdowns (five each of the past two seasons) and his 10.8 OTD and 13 end zone targets during the span suggest it's not a fluke. Of course, there's still plenty of room to grow in that department, and Kittle has plenty of dominant years left at age 26. He's a fine third-round target.

name: Jonnu Smith
bio: With Delanie Walker out of the way, Smith enters his fourth NFL season finally locked in atop the Titans' depth chart. Granted it was on 43 targets, but Smith's 2019 season was highly efficient. He ranked no lower than second at the position in catch rate (81%), YPT (10.2) or RAC (7.9). The Titans appear committed to manufacturing touches for the versatile Smith, as 19% of his targets came on screens and he also handled four carries. Of course, the usage has yet to allow much fantasy success. Most of Smith's work has come near the line of scrimmage (5.7 aDOT) and very little has come near the end zone (eight touchdowns, six end zone targets in career). Smith is a back-end TE2.

name: Jared Cook
bio: After failing to post a single fantasy campaign better than 12th during his first eight NFL seasons, Cook has posted a pair of top-seven finishes (and with different teams) over the past two seasons. Cook missed a pair of games last season, but managed a TE7 campaign thanks to nine touchdowns (his 11 end zone targets tied for most among tight ends and eighth in the league) and elite efficiency (he posted the position's highest aDOT, YPR and YPT). Cook is now 33 years old, but his role as one of Drew Brees' primary targets remains secure. Consider him a borderline top-10 fantasy option.

name: Tyler Higbee
bio: If someone told you midway through the 2019 season that Higbee was a solid TE1 fantasy option going forward, you would've laughed. The 2016 fourth-round pick had totaled an 86-884-5 receiving line in 58 games through Week 12 of last season. He went on to produce a 43-522-2 line while averaging 11.4 targets per game the rest of the season. Higbee was the top-scoring fantasy TE by 23 points during the span. The 27-year-old signed a contract extension last year and Sean McVay's adjustment to more '12' personnel late last season suggests Higbee's emergence was no fluke. Higbee is best-viewed as mid-range TE1.

name: Dallas Goedert
bio: Goedert spent the 2019 season behind Zach Ertz on the depth chart and missed a game, but still managed a top-10 finish among tight ends in targets, receptions, yardage, touchdowns and fantasy points. A big reason for the high-end production was a massive number of injuries to Eagles' wide receivers and that shows up in Goedert's splits. The 2018 second-round pick posted five top-10 fantasy weeks, but four came after the team's Week 10 bye. Goedert appears to have a bright future, but the 25-year-old will struggle for TE1 numbers barring an Ertz injury. Goedert is, however, one of the best insurance policies in fantasy.

name: Austin Hooper
bio: Hooper signed with the Browns during the offseason following four seasons with the Falcons. The 2016 third-round pick has finished no lower than seventh among tight ends in routes, targets, receptions or receiving yards each of the past two seasons. He posted career-high marks in targets (96), receptions (75), receiving yards (787) and touchdowns (six) last season despite missing three games and was fantasy's top-scoring tight end prior to suffering an injury in Week 10. Hooper's stock takes hit as he trades Matt Ryan and Atlanta's pass-heavy offense for Baker Mayfield and a Browns offense that also include David Njoku. Hooper enters his age-25 season as a borderline top-10 fantasy option.

name: Irv Smith Jr.
bio: Smith is entering his second NFL season after posting a 36-311-2 receiving line as a rookie. The 2019 second-round pick played a healthy 587 snaps, but was a clear second to Kyle Rudolph (749 snaps) on the depth chart and was primarily utilized as short-area target (5.9 aDOT). Rudolph out-targeted Smith 49 to 48, though Smith is a strong bet to take over as the team's top receiving threat at the position in his second season. Smith is still extremely young (he's entering his age-22 season), but especially with Stefon Diggs gone, he's well-positioned for a step forward. Rudolph's presence will limit his ceiling, but Smith is a fine TE2 target.

name: Tyler Eifert
bio: Eifert signed with the Jaguars during the offseason after seven seasons with the Bengals. The 2013 first-round pick held up for 16 games last season for the first time in his career, but a situational role limited him to 44% of the snaps and 4.0 targets per game. Eifert finished TE19 in fantasy, which marked his first top-20 campaign since 2015. New Jaguars OC Jay Gruden makes heavy use of his tight ends (career 23% target share), which benefits Eifert and second-year TE Josh Oliver. Of course, we still need to be wary of Eifert's durability after he missed 52 of 80 possible games during the 2014-18 seasons. Eifert is a fringe TE2 at best.

name: Zach Ertz
bio: Ertz had his hands full playing through injuries and double coverage last season, but the veteran tight end still managed his third consecutive campaign as a top-four fantasy tight end. Ertz hasn't finished lower than fifth in targets, sixth in receptions or seventh in yardage at the position since 2014. He's also ranked no lower than fourth in touchdowns and OTD each of the past three seasons. Third-year Dallas Goedert is looming, but Ertz enters his age-29 season as Carson Wentz's top target and remains a top-five fantasy tight end.

name: Chris Herndon
bio: Herndon is back on the fantasy radar following an injury-plagued 2019 campaign in which he was limited to 16 snaps. The Jets selected Herndon in the fourth round of the 2018 draft and quickly put him in position for a big role. The Miami product was on the field for 63% of New York's snaps and, following a slow start, was fantasy's No. 9 tight end from Week 6 on. His 10.3 aDOT was fifth-highest at the position and helped him to a strong 9.0 YPT (10th). Herndon's 502 receiving yards rank 12th, his catch rate 12th, his YPT fourth and his aDOT second among rookie tight ends since 2007. Herndon is an excellent post-hype target and positioned well for a breakout.

name: Darren Fells
bio: Fells re-signed with Houston during the offseason after producing the elusive 'age-33 breakout season' in 2019. Fells found the end zone seven times, which was third-most at the position. Fells was on the field often (his 704 snaps ranked 12th), but wasn't targeted much (46 targets) and benefited from unsustainable fortune in the touchdown department (3.7 OTD, six end zone targets). Fells also did a lot of his damage early on, as he delivered four top-10 fantasy weeks through Week 8, but none better than 15th from that point on. He remains well off the fantasy radar, especially with Jordan Thomas, Kahale Warring and Jordan Akins looming.

name: Kyle Rudolph
bio: Minnesota placed Rudolph on the trade block last offseason, but the situation was resolved with a contract extension and the veteran tight end finishing eighth among tight ends in snaps and fourth in touchdowns (six). Of course, sharing with Irv Smith Jr. in a run-heavy offense also had its disadvantages. Rudolph's catch (39) and yardage (367) totals were both his lowest since 2014. Rudolph remains a reliable short-area target, but he's now 30 years old and figures to lose more looks to Smith in 2020. Rudolph is no more than a fringe TE2.

name: Cameron Brate
bio: Brate might be on the TE1 radar on other rosters, but the long-time situational target continues to trend in the wrong direction in Tampa Bay. Brate posted a pair of top-10 fantasy campaigns during the 2016-17 seasons, but fell to 19th in 2018 and 24th last season. Brate has been very touchdown-reliant, having ranked no lower than eighth at the position in TD rate each of the past five seasons. Brate's 269 routes last season were his fewest since 2015 and he's unlikely to rebound with TE-unfriendly coach Bruce Arians and O.J. Howard and Rob Gronkowski in the fold. Brate is well off the fantasy radar.

name: Dawson Knox
bio: The Bills selected Knox in the third round of the 2019 draft and the Ole Miss product quickly earned his way to a significant offensive role. Knox played 64% of the offensive snaps and produced a 28-388-2 receiving line on 50 targets prior to resting in Week 17. The combination of plenty of downfield routes (his 9.2 aDOT ranked sixth) and Josh Allen's inaccuracy (20% off-target rate ranked ninth) led to an ugly 56% catch rate (second-worst), but Knox still managed a respectable 7.8 YPT (14th-best). The 23-year-old is an obvious candidate for a step forward in his second season, but with Stefon Diggs added to Buffalo's run-heavy offense, Knox is a borderline TE2 at best.

name: Cole Kmet
bio: The Bears selected Kmet with the 43rd pick of April's draft. The Notre Dame product is a solid receiver and capable blocker who also happens to be one of the youngest tight ends in this year's rookie class (he turned 21 in March). He has outstanding size (6-foot-6, 262 pounds), as well as good hands and balls skills. He has drawn Austin Hooper and Tyler Higbee comparisons as a player who figures to develop into a pass-catching in-line tight end. Like most (OK, all) young tight ends, it will take Kmet some time to reach TE1 territory, but he'll be a strong dynasty stash. Kmet has almost zero 2020 value behind Jimmy Graham.

name: Jack Doyle
bio: With Eric Ebron out of the picture, Doyle has regained his status as the Colts' clear top tight end. We got a glimpse of what that could look like late last season as Doyle tied for the team lead with 31 targets (20% share) once Ebron went on IR after Week 12. Doyle was held to two top-10 fantasy weeks and one finish better than eighth on the season, but there are reasons for optimism. Coach Frank Reich's tight end units have never combined for a target share below 23% in six seasons as a coach/OC. Also, new QB Philip Rivers made heavy usage of Antonio Gates and Hunter Henry in recent years with the Chargers. Doyle, who ranked sixth at tight end with eight end zone targets last season, should be viewed as a fringe top-15 fantasy TE in his age-30 season.

name: Harrison Bryant
bio: The Browns selected Bryant in the fourth round of April's draft. Bryant's numbers were off the charts at Florida Atlantic last season, as he averaged a class-best 3.1 yards per route run while posting a 65-1,004-7 receiving line on 99 targets. Bryant is a terrific receiver, and that figures to be his primary focus in the pros, but he's not a zero as a blocker, which could lead to the coveted every-down role. Bryant's hands are a slight concern, and he didn't show well athletically at the combine, but his receiving prowess makes him an intriguing prospect. He won't be fantasy relevant for a long time with Austin Hooper and David Njoku ahead of him in Cleveland.

name: Will Dissly
bio: Dissly is entering his third NFL season having managed only eight full games due to injury. The 2018 fourth-round pick has been very productive, producing at least 13 fantasy points in six of those eight games, but the injuries have obviously derailed his career to this point. The 24-year-old is recovering from a torn Achilles and it's very possible he won't be ready for Week 1. Seattle signed Greg Olsen during the offseason, so Dissly may struggle for consistent fantasy production at least until late in the 2020 season. He should not be drafted unless cleared earlier than expected.

name: Greg Olsen
bio: Olsen signed with the Seahawks during the offseason following 13 seasons with the Bears and Panthers. The veteran tight end missed roughly half of both the 2017 and 2018 seasons before getting back on track in 2019. Despite missing two more games, Olsen finished sixth at the position in routes and 11th in targets, receptions, yardage and OTD. He was TE13 in fantasy, though it could've been better if not for bad touchdown luck (2 TD, 4.7 OTD). Olsen is now 35 and, while his move to Seattle could allow early-season fantasy relevance, it is expected that Will Dissly will return to the lineup at some point this calendar year. Olsen is only worth a late pick in deeper leagues.

name: David Njoku
bio: Njoku was expected to emerge after Cleveland selected him in the first round of the 2017 draft. He appears to be on track after posting a 56-639-4 receiving line (TE9 in fantasy) in 2018, but injuries and a demotion courtesy of Freddie Kitchens led to a grand total of 10 targets in four games last season. It's possible tight end-friendly new head coach Kevin Stefanski can get Njoku's career back on track, but Cleveland's heavy investment in Austin Hooper is crushing for Njoku's fantasy upside. The 24-year-old is a long shot for anything more than a situational role and not worth drafting in most formats.
